answers: coordinate covalent bond [or dative bond; or donor–acceptor bond]
parts: Name this type of covalent bond formed when both electrons come from one of the two participating atoms.

Cobalt(II) (two) chloride undergoes a very pretty color change from sky blue to purple upon addition of this compound. Aquo complexes are metal compounds that feature this ligand exclusively coordinated to the central atom.

The wonderfully-named complexing agent DOTA is used to chelate (KEE-late) this element, whose high paramagnetism is caused by its seven unpaired f orbital electrons. It is commonly found in MRI contrast agents.
Name this novel about Sophie Caco, who immigrates to America, where she lives with her mother Martine and elopes with Joseph.
Breath, Eyes, Memory was written by Edwidge Danticat (don-tee-KAH), who hails from this Caribbean country. In the novel, Sophie rushes to the airport in this country's capital of Port-Au-Prince.

The 2015 Booker Prize was won by a Caribbean author with this surname for his novel A Brief History of Seven Killings. A more famous novelist of this surname wrote a trio of dense late novels featuring characters such as Milly Theale and Prince Amerigo.

answers: Vichy France [prompt on the French State]
parts: Name this Popular Front leader who twice served as the Prime Minister under President Albert Lebrun.
Blum was later imprisoned in a concentration camp after being tried by this puppet government of France that served Nazi Germany during World War II.

In April 1945, Blum and other prisoners were taken to the Tyrol region. One such prisoner, Martin Niemoller, was a pastor best known for a poem denouncing German cowardice. Give the English, three-word opening of the poem, which ends by saying "there was no one left to speak for me."

answers: Koschei (kuh-SHAY) the Deathless [or Kashchei the Immortal]
parts: Name this evil being who is typically said to have a soul hidden in a needle inside of an egg, which is in a duck, which is in a hare, which is in an iron chest buried under a green oak tree on an island.
Koschei is a villain in Slavic mythology. This chief god of the Slavs was the god of thunder and lightning.
Perun was known for wielding a hammer and this weapon, a large version of which was also carried about by the American folk hero Paul Bunyan.
What three words appear under that image in a 1754 political cartoon created to promote unity during the French and Indian War?
The "Join, or Die" cartoon was created by this Founding Father, a leading editor in Philadelphia who published Poor Richard's Almanack.
Franklin used this alias, posing as a middle-aged widow, in order to get his work published in his brother James's newspaper, the New-England Courant.

answers: Don Quixote's library [or books of Don Quixote; accept Alonso or Quixano in place of "Quixote"]
parts: Name this collection that includes such texts as Felixmarte de Hyrcania and the Fortune of Love. In a meta-reference, this collection also includes Galatea, which is judged to have "some good invention."
Both Galatea and Don Quixote were written by this Spanish author.
The offending books in Quixote's library are burned by a group consisting of his niece, his housekeeper, a parish curate, and a man who holds this occupation in town.
Name this man who was executed after being captured at Glenrowan in 1880. In that shootout, he memorably wore a homemade suit of metal armor.
Kelly was an outlaw in this modern-day country and was executed at the Old Melbourne Gaol (jail).
Kelly was one of these Australian criminals, who robbed banks and killed policemen. Their name refers to the region where they hid from the police.
Name this keto acid that is formed from oxidative decarboxylation of isocitrate during the Krebs cycle. This five-carbon molecule is then further decarboxylated to yield succinyl-CoA.

This electron carrier is also generated by the oxidative decarboxylations that form AKG and succinyl-CoA. Three of this reduced molecule and one FADH2 are made per acetyl-CoA entering the Krebs cycle.

Alpha-keto acid and pyruvate dehydrogenase complexes require the thiazolium carbanion of this coenzyme for their decarboxylation steps. This coenzyme is a derivative of the vitamin deficient in Korsakoff syndrome.

answers: unnamed [or nameless; or non-existent; or wu-ming; accept obvious equivalents] <Cheyne>
parts: Name this religion that emphasizes the "Three Treasures" of compassion, frugality, and humility.
The concept of duality within Taoism is frequently symbolized by this symbol, whose name can be translated as "dark-bright."
In the opening lines of the Tao Te Ching, Heaven and Earth are said to spring from a force that most translations list as having this quality.

answers: the cover of Abbey Road [prompt on descriptive answers involving the Beatles]
parts: Name this image, designed by art director Kosh in 1969, that features four men walking in single file from left to right. One man is barefoot and out of step with the other three.
Abbey Road, an album by this group, sports an iconic cover, as does Sgt. Pepper's Lonely Hearts Club Band, another album by them.

Bands like Molly Hatchet and Dust have frequently used this artist's work for their cover art. The definitive artist of Conan the Barbarian, he created "Death Dealer," a painting showing a menacing warrior on a horse carrying a bloody axe.
Name this function, which is generally a function of the generalized coordinates, the generalized momenta, and their time derivatives. Integrating this function with respect to time gives the action.
The Lagrangian equals the kinetic energy minus this form of energy. An object has this form of energy due to its position relative to other objects.

If the derivative of the Lagrangian with respect to a coordinate equals zero, then that coordinate is described by this term. In a system described by polar coordinates that is symmetric along the z-axis, the theta coordinate is this type of coordinate.

answers: Pope Innocent X [prompt Pope Innocent; prompt on the Pope]
Three Studies for Figures at the Base of a Crucifixion <Belal>
parts: Name this historical figure who is seen draped in a red coat and seated on a red throne in a portrait by Diego Velázquez. He is also shown screaming in a later study of that earlier portrait.

The screaming study of the portrait of Pope Innocent X was created by this British artist for his Screaming Popes series. This artist's Three Studies on his friend Lucian Freud sold for 142 million dollars back in 2013.

Bacon also produced a triptych titled Three Studies for Figures at the Base of one of these events. In that triptych, three long-necked furies from the Oresteia sit with their mouths open in front of a dark orange background.
Name this title legendarily held by seven men. The final man in this post, known as the "Proud," was supposedly overthrown shortly after raping a woman named Lucretia.
The first king of Rome, Romulus, legendarily founded Rome on the eastern banks of this Italian river.

This aforementioned king of Rome ruled during the destruction of Alba Longa. As his name indicates, he was supposedly a warlike king, and according to Livy, he died when Jupiter destroyed his home with a lightning bolt.

answers: South Korea [or the Republic of Korea; or the ROK; prompt on Korea; do not accept "Democratic People's Republic of Korea"]
a ferry sinking [accept any answer involving a ferry accident; accept synonyms like ship or boat in place of "ferry"]
parts: Name this Asian country led from 2013 to 2017 by Park Geun-hye (gun-HEH) until she was impeached for allowing her advisers to abuse their power and engage in extortion schemes.
Park's popularity dipped after over 300 people died in this type of disaster in April 2014. South Koreans perceived the government as apathetic and incompetent in response to this type of accident.

Park was especially attacked for her relationship with Choi Soon-sil (ch'WAY soon-SHEEL), the daughter of Choi Tae-min (ch'WAY TEH-meen), the founder of this Korean cult. Choi Soon-sil greatly profited from her influence over President Park.

Name this tuned percussion instrument that, in Western music, is considered to be a higher-pitched relative of the marimba. Camille Saint-Saëns (kuh-MEE san-SAWNS) used it to represent moving skeletons in the "Fossils" section of his Carnival of the Animals.
Saint-Saëns used the xylophone to represent rattling bones in this tone poem. The solo violin's E string is tuned down to an E-flat in this piece so that it can play a tritone on two open strings.
Along with his colleague Gunild Keetman, this composer developed a namesake "Schulwerk" (SHOOL-vairk) approach to music education that made heavy use of xylophones.

answers: reduplication [do not accept or prompt on "duplication"]
parts: In this morphological process common in Asian and Native American languages, part or all of a word is repeated to express a grammatical function, such as plurality or intensity.

In Celtic languages like Irish, word-initial consonants undergo this process of "weakening" in many grammatical contexts. In Irish orthography, the letter "h" is added after the consonant undergoing this phonological process, which is contrasted with fortition.
This language family uses three-consonant roots and often inflects them by inserting vowels in various places in the root. This language family includes Amharic, Arabic, and Hebrew.
Name this man who engaged in such weird behavior as sleeping in a ceramic jar in the marketplace and carrying a lamp in the daytime, claiming that he was looking for an honest man.

The thought of Cynic philosophers like Diogenes was adapted by Zeno of Citium into this philosophical school, which emphasized controlling destructive emotions. The Roman Emperor Marcus Aurelius followed this philosophy.

Diogenes was called the "faithful hound" of this man because, according to legend, he doggedly pursued him. This student of Socrates argued that virtue, not pleasure, was the end of existence, and he is sometimes considered the founder of Cynicism.

answers: We Have Always Lived in the Castle
parts: Name this novel set in Vermont, in which Merricat confesses to her sister Constance that she put arsenic in their family's blackberries several years earlier, killing four people.

The author of We Have Always Lived in the Castle, Shirley Jackson, also wrote this short story that ends with Tessie Hutchinson "winning" the title contest and being stoned to death by the other villagers.
This Jackson novel features Dr. Montague investigating the supernatural at the title location. It ends with Eleanor Vance dying in a car accident.

answers: differentiation [or taking derivatives; accept word forms] <Thompson>
parts: Identify this largest sporadic group that contains more than 8 times 10-to-the-53 elements. Its connections to modular forms are the subject of moonshine theory.

The construction of the Monster group was the final step in the classification of finite simple groups, which categorized almost all finite simple groups into Lie (lee) groups, alternating groups, and these groups that have exactly one generator. These groups are isomorphic to additive groups under modular arithmetic.

Modular forms are meromorphic, meaning that the complex version of this operation can be performed except at the forms' poles. This operation is done repeatedly to compute a function's Taylor series, as the first two applications of this operation determine slope and concavity.

answers: penny dreadfuls [or penny horribles; or penny awfuls; or penny bloods; prompt on penny novels]
highwayman [prompt on criminal; prompt on thief] <Cheyne>
parts: Name this genre of cheap, sensationalized fiction published during Victorian-era Britain. Their name refers to their cheap price and their usual focus on horror or crime tales.
A popular penny dreadful serial told the story of "Varney," one of these creatures. Bram Stoker's Count Dracula is a more famous one of these beings.
Another popular serial focused on the character Dick Turpin, who rode the horse Black Bess. Turpin held this specific occupation until his death in 1739.
Name this Papal bull issued by Boniface VIII that affirmed the church's supremacy over sovereign states.
Boniface issued the bull Ausculta Fili to persuade this country's monarch, Philip the Fair, to cease his evil ways. Philip was a member of the House of Capet (kah-PAY).

Along with Sciarra Colonna (SHAR-ah koh-LONE-ah), this keeper of the seal under Philip the Fair tried to kidnap Boniface VIII. This man believed the untimely deaths of Boniface and his successor, Benedict XI, proved the justice of his cause.
